Award.AwardTitle: METABOLOMICS: Integrating cheminformatic resources for investigating photoautotrophic and mixotrophic metabolism in algae.
Award.AbstractNarration:
The metabolome is the sum total of the products of chemical reactions in the cell; it comprises a diverse set of chemicals that is species-specific and that is strongly influenced by the environment. Thus, despite decades of biochemical research, metabolomics is a field that is still in development, and no comprehensive database captures the complement of species-dependent metabolites. This project will capture the metabolome of 10 photosynthetic microorganisms (algae) by identifying all detectable metabolites that are synthesized as building blocks during their growth under conditions with variable sources of carbon (for example carbon dioxide and other organic compounds, including those found in wastewater). These data will greatly increase our knowledge of algal metabolism and carbon utilization. A major goal of this project is to integrate and improve existing metabolomic databases and libraries and to build new tools for the fast identification of metabolites. The resources resulting from this project will be made freely available to foster collaborations across multiple disciplines including engineering, analytical chemistry and bioinformatics. This project will facilitate the development of more efficient technologies for biofuel production based on photosynthetic microorganisms.

Broader Impacts
This project, through collaborations with researchers at the University of Tokyo and Osaka Prefectural University, will integrate and freely disseminate information and tutorials about libraries of chemical data, chemistry software, laboratory protocols for metabolism studies and results from the algal metabolomic studies. Web-based access will enable researchers and others interested in using these tools to compare the biochemistry of different species under various environmental conditions. In addition to the international training and education of the next generation of researchers, there will be outreach by project participants to students and pupils in K-12 education through the NSF-REU and GK-12 programs. Project staff will participate in the BioTech SYSTEM biotechnology program for teachers by providing educational activities for high school students and by partnering with local schools with large populations of under-served and under-represented minority students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was the first common funded scientific collaboration between US-based scientists and science laboratories in Japan. Both groups were funded by their respective agencies by collaborating on identical topics and themes. Here, our main interaction partner was Prof. Masanori Arita, a scientist involved with providing information resources for small molecules in plants and algae, called metabolites. There are hundreds of thousands of metabolites in nature, for many purposes ranging from defense and communication, to providing energy and growth. These metabolites were analyzed in detail by our laboratory at UC Davis using specialized equipment called mass spectrometers. Such instruments acquire mass spectra that can be used for quantifying the amount of metabolites in algae and plants, but also for identifying such small molecules.

 

In collaboration with our Japanese partners, we developed new databases and software for comprehensive analysis of metabolites. First, we enlarged and improved databases for mass spectra, providing a new resource at http://massbank.us This database today contains more than 220,000 mass spectra for more than 80,000 different molecules. More than 5,000 scientists per year download the database for use in their laboratories, and many more scientists perform direct searches. Overall, we published 29 peer-reviewed scientific reports through this award. Another important software we published in collaboration with our Japanese colleagues was a new, easy-to-use program for untargeted screening of all metabolites in a sample, called MS-DIAL. We published this tool in Nature which led to hundreds of citations to date, and many further users. Third, we published another software to identify chemical structures of metabolites from mass spectra, using novel types of predictions compared to alternative programs. This tool, MS-FINDER, has led to numerous new compound identifications, with impact beyond plant and algae metabolism but discovering new oncometabolites such as N-methyl-UMP that are hundredfold increased in human cancers. This example shows that our NSF project had impact beyond the immediate realm of basic science and fundamental biology.

 

We also provided numerous opportunities for training young scientists. We organized the international conferences of the Metabolomics Societies in both Japan and the U.S., we held more than 10 workshops and symposia, and we had numerous visits between both countries for scientific collaborative purposes. Over 50 undergraduate students were trained in laboratory work at UC Davis alone, and more than 500 participants came to our workshops. In addition, we held two professional training courses per year, with hands-on training on laptops that were dedicated for exercises on metabolic investigations, statistics and data interpretations.
